verse	44	19	4	Then Paul said, "John indeed baptized with a baptism of repentance, saying to the people that they should believe on Him who would come after him, that is, on Christ Jesus."
verse	44	19	5	When they heard this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
verse	44	19	6	And when Paul had laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came upon them, and they spoke with tongues and prophesied.
verse	44	19	7	Now the men were about twelve in all.
verse	44	19	8	And he went into the synagogue and spoke boldly for the space of three months, disputing and persuading the things concerning the kingdom of God.
verse	44	19	9	But when some were hardened and did not believe, but spoke evil of the Way before the crowd, he departed from them and withdrew the disciples, reasoning daily in the school of one Tyrannus.
verse	44	19	10	And this continued for the space of two years, so that all those who dwelt in Asia heard the word of the Lord Jesus, both Jews and Greeks.
verse	44	19	11	Now God worked unusual miracles by the hands of Paul,
verse	44	19	12	so that handkerchiefs or aprons were brought from his body to the sick, and the diseases left them and the evil spirits went out of them.
verse	44	19	13	Then some of the itinerant Jewish exorcists took it upon themselves to call the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, "We exorcise you by Jesus whom Paul preaches."
verse	44	19	14	And there were seven sons of one Sceva, a Jew and chief priest, who did so.
verse	44	19	15	And the evil spirit replied and said, "Jesus I know, and Paul I know; but who are you?"
verse	44	19	16	Then the man in whom the evil spirit was leaped on them, overpowered them, and prevailed against them, so that they fled out of that house naked and wounded.
verse	44	19	17	This became known both to all Jews and Greeks dwelling in Ephesus; and fear fell on them all, and the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
verse	44	19	18	And many who had believed came confessing and telling their deeds.
verse	44	19	19	Also, many of those who had practiced magic brought their books together and burned them in the sight of everyone. And they counted up the value of them, and it totaled fifty thousand pieces of silver.
verse	44	19	20	So the word of God grew mightily and prevailed.
verse	44	19	21	When these things were accomplished, Paul purposed in the Spirit, when he had passed through Macedonia and Achaia, to go to Jerusalem, saying, "After I have been there, I must also see Rome."
verse	44	19	22	So he sent into Macedonia two of those who ministered to him, Timothy and Erastus, but he himself stayed in Asia for a season.
verse	44	19	23	And about that time there arose no small commotion about the Way.
verse	44	19	24	Because, a certain man named Demetrius, a silversmith, who made silver shrines of Diana, brought no small profit to the craftsmen,
verse	44	19	25	whom he called together with the workers of similar occupation, and said: "Men, you know that we have our wealth by this trade.
verse	44	19	26	Moreover you see and hear that not only at Ephesus, but throughout almost all Asia, this Paul has persuaded and turned away many people, saying that they are not gods which are made with hands.
verse	44	19	27	So that not only is this trade of ours in danger of becoming disgraced, but also the temple of the great goddess Diana may be despised and her magnificence shall be destroyed, whom all Asia and the world worship."
verse	44	19	28	Now when they heard these words, they were full of wrath and shouted out, saying, "Great is Diana of the Ephesians!"
verse	44	19	29	So the entire city was filled with confusion, and having seized Gaius and Aristarchus, Macedonians, Paul's travel companions, they rushed into the theater with one accord.
verse	44	19	30	And when Paul wanted to go in to the people, the disciples would not allow him.
verse	44	19	31	Then some of the officials of Asia, who were his friends, sent to him begging him that he himself would not venture into the theater.
verse	44	19	32	Some therefore shouted one thing and some another, because the assembly was confused, and most of them did not know why they had come together.
verse	44	19	33	And they drew Alexander out of the crowd, the Jews putting him forward. And Alexander motioned with his hand, and wanted to make his defense to the people.
verse	44	19	34	But when they found out that he was a Jew, all with one voice shouted out for about the space of two hours, "Great is Diana of the Ephesians!"
verse	44	19	35	And when the city clerk had quieted the crowd, he said: "You men of Ephesus, what man is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is a worshipper of the great goddess Diana, and of the image which fell down from Jupiter?
verse	44	19	36	Therefore, since these things cannot be denied, you ought to be quiet and do nothing rashly.
verse	44	19	37	Because, you have brought these men here who are neither robbers of temples nor blasphemers of your goddess.
verse	44	19	38	Therefore, if Demetrius and his fellow craftsmen who are with him, have a case against anyone, the courts are open and there are proconsuls. Let them bring charges against one another.
verse	44	19	39	But if you have inquire anything concerning other matters, it should be determined in the lawful assembly.
verse	44	19	40	Because, we are in danger of being called in question for today's uproar, there being no reason which we may give to account for this commotion."
verse	44	19	41	And when he had said these things, he dismissed the assembly.
verse	44	20	1	After the uproar had ceased, Paul called the disciples to himself, embraced them, and departed to go to Macedonia.
verse	44	20	2	Now when he had gone over that region and encouraged them with many words, he came into Greece
verse	44	20	3	and stayed there three months. And when the Jews plotted against him as he was about to sail to Syria, he decided to return through Macedonia.
verse	44	20	4	And Sopater of Berea accompanied him to Asia, also Aristarchus and Secundus of the Thessalonians, and Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy, and of Asia Tychicus and Trophimus.
verse	44	20	5	These, going ahead, waited for us at Troas.
verse	44	20	6	But we sailed away from Philippi after the Days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days joined them at Troas, where we stayed seven days.
verse	44	20	7	Now on the first day of the week, when the disciples came together to break bread, Paul, ready to depart the next day, preached to them and continued his message until midnight.
verse	44	20	8	There were many lamps in the upper room where they were gathered together.
verse	44	20	9	And in a window sat a certain young man named Eutychus, who was falling into a deep sleep. He was overcome by sleep; and as Paul continued preaching, he fell down from the third story and was taken up dead.
verse	44	20	10	But Paul went down, fell on him, and embracing him said, "Do not trouble yourselves, because his life is in him."
verse	44	20	11	Now when he had come up again, had broken bread and eaten, and talked a long while, even until daybreak, he departed.
verse	44	20	12	And they brought the young man in alive, and they were not a little comforted.
verse	44	20	13	Then we went ahead to the ship and sailed to Assos, there intending to take Paul on board; because he had given orders, intending himself to go on foot.
verse	44	20	14	And when he met us at Assos, we took him on board and came to Mitylene.
verse	44	20	15	We sailed from there, and the next day came opposite Chios. The following day we arrived at Samos and stayed at Trogyllium. The next day we came to Miletus.
verse	44	20	16	Because, Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus, so that he would not have to spend time in Asia; because he was hurrying to be at Jerusalem, if possible, on the Day of Pentecost.
verse	44	20	17	From Miletus he sent to Ephesus and called for the elders of the church.
verse	44	20	18	And when they had come to him, he said to them: "You know, from the first day that I came to Asia, in what manner I always lived among you, in every season
verse	44	20	19	serving the Lord with all humility of mind, with many tears and trials which happened to me by the plotting of the Jews;
verse	44	20	20	and how I kept back nothing that was helpful to you, but have shown you, and taught you publicly and from house to house,
verse	44	20	21	testifying both to Jews, and also to Greeks, repentance toward God and faith toward our Lord Jesus Christ.
verse	44	20	22	And behold, now I go bound in the spirit to Jerusalem, not knowing the things that shall happen to me there,
verse	44	20	23	except that the Holy Spirit witnesses in every city, saying that chains and afflictions await me.
verse	44	20	24	But none of these things move me; nor do I count my life dear to myself, so that I may finish my race with joy, and the ministry which I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify the gospel of the grace of God.
verse	44	20	25	"And indeed, now I know that you all, among whom I have gone preaching the kingdom of God, will see my face no longer.
verse	44	20	26	Therefore I want you to record this day that I am innocent of the blood of all people.
verse	44	20	27	Because I have not shunned to declare to you the entire counsel of God.
verse	44	20	28	Therefore take heed to yourselves and to all the flock, among whom the Holy Spirit has made you overseers, to feed the church of God which He purchased with His own blood.
verse	44	20	29	Because I know this, that after my departure savage wolves will come in among you, not sparing the flock.
verse	44	20	30	Also from among yourselves men will rise up, speaking perverse things, to draw away disciples after themselves.
verse	44	20	31	Therefore watch, and remember that for the space of three years I did not cease to warn everyone night and day with tears.
verse	44	20	32	"So now, brethren, I commend you to God and to the word of His grace, which is able to build you up and give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.
verse	44	20	33	I have coveted no one's silver or gold or apparel.
verse	44	20	34	Yes, you yourselves know that these hands have provided for my necessities, and for those who were with me.
verse	44	20	35	I have shown you in everything, by laboring like this, that you must support the weak. And remember the words of the Lord Jesus, that He said, 'It is more blessed to give than to receive.'"
verse	44	20	36	And when he had said these things, he knelt down and prayed with them all.
verse	44	20	37	Then they all wept freely, and fell on Paul's neck and kissed him,
verse	44	20	38	sorrowing most of all for the words which he spoke, that they would see his face no longer. And they accompanied him to the ship.
verse	44	21	1	Now it came to pass, that when we had departed from them and set sail, running a straight course we came to Cos, the following day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
verse	44	21	2	And finding a ship sailing over to Phoenicia, we went aboard and set sail.
verse	44	21	3	When we had sighted Cyprus, we passed it on the left, sailed to Syria, and landed at Tyre; because there the ship was to unload her cargo.
verse	44	21	4	And finding disciples, we stayed there seven days. They told Paul through the Spirit that he should not go up to Jerusalem.
verse	44	21	5	And when we had come to the end of those days, we departed and went on our way; and they all accompanied us, with wives and children, until we were out of the city. And we knelt down on the shore and prayed.
verse	44	21	6	When we had taken our leave of one another, we boarded the ship, and they returned home again.
verse	44	21	7	And when we had finished our voyage from Tyre, we came to Ptolemais, greeted the brethren, and stayed with them one day.
verse	44	21	8	On the next day we who were Paul's companions departed and came to Caesarea, and entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, and stayed with him.
verse	44	21	9	Now this man had four virgin daughters who prophesied.
verse	44	21	10	And as we stayed there several days, a certain prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
verse	44	21	11	When he had come to us, he took Paul's belt, bound his own hands and feet, and said, "Thus says the Holy Spirit, 'So will the Jews at Jerusalem bind the man who owns this belt, and will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.'"
verse	44	21	12	Now when we heard these things, both we and those from that place pleaded with him not to go up to Jerusalem.
verse	44	21	13	Then Paul replied, "What do you mean by weeping and breaking my heart? Because I am ready not only to be bound, but also to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus."
verse	44	21	14	So when he would not be persuaded, we ceased, saying, "The will of the Lord be done."
verse	44	21	15	And after those days we took up our belongings and went up to Jerusalem.
verse	44	21	16	Also some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us and brought with them one Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we were to lodge.
verse	44	21	17	And when we had come to Jerusalem, the brethren received us gladly.
verse	44	21	18	On the following day Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders were present.
verse	44	21	19	When he had greeted them, he told in detail those things which God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
verse	44	21	20	And when they heard it, they glorified the Lord. And they said to him, "You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are who believe, and they are all zealous for the law;
verse	44	21	21	but they have been informed about you that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, saying that they ought not to circumcise their children nor to walk according to the customs.
verse	44	21	22	What is it then? The assembly must certainly meet, because they will hear that you have come.
verse	44	21	23	Therefore do what we tell you: We have four men who have taken a vow upon themselves.
verse	44	21	24	Take them and purify yourself with them, and pay their expenses so that they may shave their heads, and that all may know that those things of which they were informed concerning you are nothing, but that you yourself also walk orderly and keep the law.
verse	44	21	25	But concerning the Gentiles who believe, we have written and concluded that they should observe no such thing, except that they should keep themselves from things offered to idols, from blood, from things strangled, and from sexual immorality."
verse	44	21	26	Then Paul took the men, and the next day, purifying himself with them, entered into the temple to signify the conclusion of the days of purification, at which time an offering should be made for each one of them.
verse	44	21	27	Now when the seven days were almost ended, the Jews from Asia, when they saw him in the temple, stirred up all the people and laid hands on him,
verse	44	21	28	shouting out, "Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches all men everywhere against the people, the law, and this place; and furthermore he also brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place."
verse	44	21	29	(Because, they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, whom they supposed that Paul had brought into the temple.)
verse	44	21	30	And all the city was disturbed; and the people ran together, seized Paul, and dragged him out of the temple; and immediately the doors were shut.
verse	44	21	31	Now as they were seeking to kill him, news came to the commander of the garrison that all Jerusalem was in an uproar.
verse	44	21	32	He immediately took soldiers and centurions, and ran down to them. And when they saw the commander and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verse	44	21	33	Then the commander came near and took him, and commanded him to be bound with two chains; and he asked who he was and what he had done.
verse	44	21	34	And some among the crowd shouted one thing and some another. So when he could not be certain of the truth because of the tumult, he commanded him to be carried into the barracks.
verse	44	21	35	When he reached the stairs, it happened that he had to be carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the mob.
verse	44	21	36	Because the crowd of the people followed after, shouting out, "Away with him!"
verse	44	21	37	Then as Paul was about to be led into the barracks, he said to the commander, "May I speak to you?" He replied, "Can you speak Greek?
verse	44	21	38	Are you not the Egyptian who some time ago stirred up a rebellion and led the four thousand assassins out into the wilderness?"
verse	44	21	39	But Paul said, "I am a man who is a Jew from Tarsus, in Cilicia, a citizen of no obscure city; and I implore you, permit me to speak to the people."
verse	44	21	40	So when he had given him permission, Paul stood on the stairs and motioned with his hand to the people. And when there was a great silence, he spoke to them in the Hebrew language, saying,
verse	44	22	1	"Men, brethren, and fathers, hear my defense which I make before you now."
verse	44	22	2	And when they heard that he spoke to them in the Hebrew language, they kept all the more silent. Then he said:
verse	44	22	3	"I am indeed a man who is a Jew, born in Tarsus a city in Cilicia, but brought up in this city at the feet of Gamaliel, taught according to the perfect method of our fathers' law, and was zealous toward God as you all are today.
verse	44	22	4	And I persecuted this Way to the death, binding and delivering into prisons both men and women,
verse	44	22	5	as also the high priest bears me witness, and all the council of the elders, from whom I also received letters to the brethren, and went to Damascus to bring those who were there in chains to Jerusalem to be punished.
verse	44	22	6	"Now it happened, as I journeyed and came near Damascus at about noon, suddenly a great light from heaven shone around me.
verse	44	22	7	And I fell to the ground and heard a voice saying to me, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me?'"
verse	44	22	8	So I replied, 'Who are You, Lord?' And He said to me, 'I am Jesus of Nazareth, whom you are persecuting.'"
verse	44	22	9	"And those who were with me indeed saw the light and were afraid, but they did not hear the voice of Him who spoke to me.
verse	44	22	10	So I said, 'What shall I do, Lord?' And the Lord said to me, 'Arise and go into Damascus, and there you will be told all things which are appointed for you to do.'"
verse	44	22	11	And since I could not see because of the glory of that light, being led by the hand of those who were with me, I came into Damascus.
verse	44	22	12	"Then a certain Ananias, a devout man according to the law, having a good testimony with all the Jews who dwelt there,
verse	44	22	13	came to me; and he stood and said to me, 'Brother Saul, receive your sight.' And at that same hour I looked up at him.
verse	44	22	14	Then he said, 'The God of our fathers has chosen you that you should know His will, and see the Just One, and hear the voice of His mouth.
verse	44	22	15	Because, you will be His witness to all people of what you have seen and heard.
verse	44	22	16	And now why are you waiting? Arise and be baptized, and wash away your sins, calling on the name of the Lord.'
verse	44	22	17	"Now it happened, when I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, that I was in a trance
verse	44	22	18	and saw Him saying to me, 'Make haste and get out of Jerusalem quickly, because they will not receive your testimony concerning Me.'"
verse	44	22	19	So I said, 'Lord, they know that in every synagogue I imprisoned and beat those who believe on You.
verse	44	22	20	And when the blood of Your martyr Stephen was shed, I also was standing by consenting to his death, and guarding the clothes of those who were killing him.'
verse	44	22	21	Then He said to me, 'Depart, because I will send you far from here to the Gentiles.'"
verse	44	22	22	And they listened to him until this word, and then they raised their voices and said, "Away with such a man from the earth, because he is not fit to live!"
verse	44	22	23	Then, as they shouted out and tore off their clothes and threw dust into the air,
verse	44	22	24	the commander ordered him to be brought into the barracks, and said that he should be examined under scourging, so that he might know why they shouted like this against him.
verse	44	22	25	And as they bound him with thongs, Paul said to the centurion who stood by, "Is it lawful for you to scourge a man who is a Roman, and uncondemned?"
verse	44	22	26	When the centurion heard that, he went and told the commander, saying, "Take care what you do, because this man is a Roman."
verse	44	22	27	Then the commander came and said to him, "Tell me, are you a Roman?" He said, "Yes."
verse	44	22	28	The commander replied, "With a large sum I obtained this freedom." And Paul said, "But I was born a free."
verse	44	22	29	Then immediately those who were about to examine him withdrew from him; and the commander was also afraid after he found out that he was a Roman, and because he had bound him.
verse	44	22	30	The next day, because he wanted to know for certain why he was accused by the Jews, he released him from his bonds, and commanded the chief priests and all their council to appear, and brought Paul down and set him before them.
verse	44	23	1	Then Paul, looking earnestly at the council, said, "Men and brethren, I have lived in all good conscience before God until this day."
verse	44	23	2	And the high priest Ananias commanded those who stood by him to strike him on the mouth.
verse	44	23	3	Then Paul said to him, "God will strike you, you whitewashed wall! Because, you sit to judge me according to the law, and do you command me to be struck contrary to the law?"
verse	44	23	4	And those who stood by said, "Do you revile God's high priest?"
verse	44	23	5	Then Paul said, "I did not know, brethren, that he was the high priest; because it is written, 'You shall not speak evil of a ruler of your people.'"
verse	44	23	6	But when Paul perceived that one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he shouted out in the council, "Men and brethren, I am a Pharisee, the son of a Pharisee; concerning the hope and resurrection of the dead I am being questioned!"
verse	44	23	7	And when he had said this, a dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees; and the assembly was divided.
verse	44	23	8	Because, Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit; but the Pharisees confess both.
verse	44	23	9	Then there arose a loud uproar. And the scribes who were of the Pharisees' company arose and protested, saying, "We find no evil in this man; but if a spirit or an angel has spoken to him, let us not fight against God."
verse	44	23	10	Now when there arose a great dissension, the commander, fearing lest Paul might be pulled to pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him by force from among them, and bring him into the barracks.
verse	44	23	11	But the following night the Lord stood by him and said, "Be of good cheer Paul; because, as you have testified of Me in Jerusalem, so you must also bear witness at Rome."
verse	44	23	12	And when it was day, some of the Jews banded together and bound themselves under an oath, saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.
verse	44	23	13	Now there were more than forty who had formed this conspiracy.
verse	44	23	14	They came to the chief priests and elders, and said, "We have bound ourselves under a great oath that we will eat nothing until we have killed Paul.
verse	44	23	15	Now you, therefore, together with the council, suggest to the commander that he be brought down to you tomorrow, as though you were going to make further inquiries concerning him; but we are ready to kill him before he comes near."
verse	44	23	16	So when Paul's sister's son heard of their ambush, he went and entered the barracks and told Paul.
verse	44	23	17	Then Paul called one of the centurions to him and said, "Take this young man to the commander, because he has something to tell him."
verse	44	23	18	So he took him and brought him to the commander and said, "Paul the prisoner called me to him and asked me to bring this young man to you. He has something to say to you."
verse	44	23	19	Then the commander took him by the hand, went aside with him, and asked him privately, "What is it that you have to tell me?"
verse	44	23	20	And he said, "The Jews have agreed to ask that you bring Paul down to the council tomorrow, as though they were going to inquire more fully about him.
verse	44	23	21	But do not yield to them, because more than forty of them lie in wait for him, men who have bound themselves by an oath that they will neither eat nor drink until they have killed him; and now they are ready, waiting for the promise from you."
verse	44	23	22	So then the commander let the young man depart, and commanded him, "See that you tell no one that you have revealed these things to me."
verse	44	23	23	And he called two centurions to himself, saying, "Prepare two hundred soldiers, seventy horsemen, and two hundred spearmen to go to Caesarea at the third hour of the night;
verse	44	23	24	and provide for them animals to set Paul upon, and bring him safely to Felix the governor."
verse	44	23	25	Then he wrote a letter in the following manner:
verse	44	23	26	Claudius Lysias, to the most excellent governor Felix: I send Greetings.
verse	44	23	27	This man was seized by the Jews and would have been killed by them. Then I came with the troops and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman.
verse	44	23	28	And when I wanted to know the reason they accused him, I brought him before their council.
verse	44	23	29	I perceived that he was accused concerning questions of their law, but had nothing charged against him deserving of death or chains.
verse	44	23	30	And when it was told me that the Jews lay in wait for the man, I sent him immediately to you, and also commanded his accusers to state before you the charges they had against him. Farewell.
verse	44	23	31	Then the soldiers, as they were commanded, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris.
verse	44	23	32	On the next day, they left the horsemen to go on with him, and returned to the barracks.
verse	44	23	33	Who when they came to Caesarea and had delivered the letter to the governor, they also presented Paul to him.
verse	44	23	34	And when the governor had read the letter, he asked what province he was from. And when he understood that he was from Cilicia,
verse	44	23	35	he said, "I will hear you when your accusers also have come." And he commanded him to be kept in Herod's judgment hall.
verse	44	24	1	Now after five days Ananias the high priest came down with the elders and with a certain orator named Tertullus, who gave evidence to the governor against Paul.
verse	44	24	2	And when he was called upon, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying: "Seeing that through you we enjoy great peace, and very admirable deeds are done to this nation by your foresight,
verse	44	24	3	we accept it always and in all places, most noble Felix, with all thankfulness.
verse	44	24	4	Nevertheless, not to be tedious to you any further, I beg you to hear, by your courtesy, a few words from us.
verse	44	24	5	Because, we have found this man a plague, a creator of dissension among all the Jews throughout the world, and a ringleader of the cult of the Nazarenes.
verse	44	24	6	He even tried to profane the temple, and we seized him, and wanted to judge him according to our law.
verse	44	24	7	But the commander Lysias went above us and with great violence took him out of our hands,
verse	44	24	8	commanding his accusers to come to you. By examining him yourself you may ascertain all these things of which we accuse him."
verse	44	24	9	And the Jews also assented, maintaining that these things were so.
verse	44	24	10	Then Paul, after the governor had motioned to him to speak, replied: "Inasmuch as I know that you have been for many years a judge of this nation, I do the more cheerfully answer for myself,
verse	44	24	11	because, you may ascertain that it is no more than twelve days since I went up to Jerusalem to worship.
verse	44	24	12	And they neither found me in the temple disputing with anyone nor inciting the people, either in the synagogues or in the city.
verse	44	24	13	Nor can they prove the things of which they now accuse me.
verse	44	24	14	But this I confess to you, that according to the Way which they call heresy, so I worship the God of my fathers, believing all things which are written in the Law and in the Prophets.
verse	44	24	15	I have hope in God, which they themselves also accept, that there will be a resurrection of the dead, both of the just and the unjust.
verse	44	24	16	And in this I always strive to have a conscience without offense toward God and towards men.
verse	44	24	17	"Now after many years I came to bring charitable gifts and offerings to my nation,
verse	44	24	18	in the midst of which some Jews from Asia found me purified in the temple, neither with a mob nor with tumult.
verse	44	24	19	They ought to have been here before you to object if they had anything against me.
verse	44	24	20	Or else let these people here say if they found any wrongdoing in me while I stood before the council,
verse	44	24	21	unless it is for this one statement which I shouted, standing among them, 'Concerning the resurrection of the dead I am being judged by you this day.'"
verse	44	24	22	But when Felix heard these things, having more accurate knowledge of that Way, he deferred them and said, "When Lysias the commander comes down, I will make a decision on your case."
verse	44	24	23	So he commanded the centurion to guard Paul and to let him have liberty, and that he should not forbid any of his friends to provide for or visit him.
verse	44	24	24	And after some days, when Felix came with his wife Drusilla, who was Jewish, he sent for Paul and heard him concerning the faith in Christ.
verse	44	24	25	Now as he reasoned about righteousness, self control, and judgment to come, Felix was afraid and replied, "Go away for now; when I have a convenient time I will call for you."
verse	44	24	26	He also hoped that money would be given him by Paul, that he might release him. Therefore he sent for him more often and conversed with him.
verse	44	24	27	But after two years Porcius Festus succeeded Felix' office; and Felix, wanting to do the Jews a favor, left Paul bound.
verse	44	25	1	Now when Festus had come into the province, after three days he went up from Caesarea to Jerusalem.
verse	44	25	2	Then the high priest and the chief men of the Jews informed him against Paul; and they petitioned him,
verse	44	25	3	asking a favor against him, that he would summon him to Jerusalem, while they lay in ambush along the road to kill him.
verse	44	25	4	But Festus replied that Paul should be kept at Caesarea, and that he himself was going there shortly.
verse	44	25	5	"Therefore," he said, "let those who are able among you go down with me and accuse this man, to see if there is any fault in him."
verse	44	25	6	And when he had remained among them more than ten days, he went down to Caesarea. And the next day, sitting on the judgment seat, he commanded Paul to be brought.
verse	44	25	7	When he had come, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood about and laid many serious complaints against Paul, which they could not prove,
verse	44	25	8	while he answered for himself, "Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor even against Caesar have I offended in anything at all."
verse	44	25	9	But Festus, wanting to do the Jews a favor, replied to Paul and said, "Are you willing to go up to Jerusalem and there be judged before me concerning these things?"
verse	44	25	10	So Paul said, "I stand at Caesar's judgment seat, where I ought to be judged. To the Jews I have done no wrong, as you very well know.
verse	44	25	11	Because if I am an offender, or have committed anything deserving of death, I do not object to dying; but if there is nothing in these things of which these men accuse me, no one can deliver me to them. I appeal to Caesar."
verse	44	25	12	Then Festus, when he had conferred with the council, replied, "You have appealed to Caesar? To Caesar you will go!"
verse	44	25	13	And after some days King Agrippa and Bernice came to Caesarea to greet Festus.
verse	44	25	14	And when they had been there many days, Festus laid Paul's case before the king, saying: "There is a certain man left a prisoner by Felix,
verse	44	25	15	about whom the chief priests and the elders of the Jews informed me, when I was in Jerusalem, asking to have judgment against him.
verse	44	25	16	To them I replied, 'It is not the custom of the Romans to deliver any man to die before the accused meets the accusers face to face, and has opportunity to answer for himself concerning the charge against him.'
verse	44	25	17	Therefore when they had come here, without any delay, the next day I sat on the judgment seat and commanded the man to be brought in.
verse	44	25	18	When the accusers stood up, they brought no accusation against him of such things as I supposed,
verse	44	25	19	but had some questions against him about their own superstition and about a certain Jesus, who had died, whom Paul affirmed to be alive.
verse	44	25	20	And because I was uncertain of such questions, I asked him whether he was willing to go to Jerusalem and there be judged concerning these matters.
verse	44	25	21	But when Paul appealed to be reserved for the decision of Augustus, I commanded him to be kept until I could send him to Caesar."
verse	44	25	22	Then Agrippa said to Festus, "I also would like to hear the man myself." "Tomorrow," he said, "you will hear him."
verse	44	25	23	So on the next day, when Agrippa and Bernice had come with great fanfare, and had entered the auditorium with the commanders and the prominent men of the city, at Festus' command Paul was brought in.
verse	44	25	24	And Festus said: "King Agrippa and all the men who are here present with us, you see this man about whom the entire assembly of the Jews petitioned me, both at Jerusalem and also here, shouting that he was not fit to live any longer.
verse	44	25	25	But when I found that he had committed nothing deserving of death, and that he himself had appealed to Augustus, I decided to send him.
verse	44	25	26	I have nothing certain to write to my lord concerning him. Therefore I have brought him out before you, and especially before you, O King Agrippa, so that after the examination has taken place I may have something to write.
verse	44	25	27	Because, it seems to me unreasonable to send a prisoner and not to specify the charges laid against him."
verse	44	26	1	Then Agrippa said to Paul, "You are permitted to speak for yourself." So Paul stretched out his hand and answered for himself:
verse	44	26	2	"I think myself happy, King Agrippa, because today I will answer for myself before you concerning all the things of which I am accused by the Jews,
verse	44	26	3	especially because I know that you are an expert in all customs and questions which have to do with the Jews. Therefore I beg you to hear me patiently.
verse	44	26	4	"My manner of life from my youth, which was spent from the beginning among my own nation at Jerusalem, all the Jews know.
verse	44	26	5	Who knew me from the beginning, if they were willing to testify, that according to the strictest sect of our religion I lived a Pharisee.
verse	44	26	6	And now I stand and am judged for the hope of the promise made by God to our fathers.
verse	44	26	7	To this promise our twelve tribes, earnestly serving God night and day, hope to attain. For this hope's sake, King Agrippa, I am accused by the Jews.
verse	44	26	8	Why should it be thought an improbable thing by you that God raises the dead?
verse	44	26	9	"Truly, I myself thought I must do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth.
verse	44	26	10	This I also did in Jerusalem, and many of the saints I shut up in prison, having received authority from the chief priests; and when they were put to death, I cast my voice against them.
verse	44	26	11	And I punished them often in every synagogue and compelled them to blaspheme; and being exceedingly enraged against them, I persecuted them even to foreign cities.
verse	44	26	12	"Being preoccupied with this, as I journeyed to Damascus with authority and commission from the chief priests,
verse	44	26	13	at midday, O king, along the road I saw a light from heaven, brighter than the sun, shining around me and those who journeyed with me.
verse	44	26	14	And when we all had fallen to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me and saying in the Hebrew language, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting Me? It is hard for you to kick against the prods.'"
verse	44	26	15	So I said, 'Who are You, Lord?' And He said, 'I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting."
verse	44	26	16	But rise and stand on your feet; because I have appeared to you for this reason, to make you a minister and a witness both of the things which you have seen and of the things which I will yet reveal to you."
verse	44	26	17	Delivering you from the people, and from the Gentiles, to whom I now send you,"
verse	44	26	18	to open their eyes, to turn them from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they may receive forgiveness of sins and an inheritance among those who are sanctified by faith that is in Me.'"
verse	44	26	19	"Therefore, King Agrippa, I was not disobedient to the heavenly vision,
verse	44	26	20	but declared first to those in Damascus and in Jerusalem, and throughout all the region of Judea, and then to the Gentiles, that they should repent, turn to God, and do works befitting repentance.
verse	44	26	21	For these reasons the Jews seized me in the temple and tried to kill me.
verse	44	26	22	Therefore, having obtained help from God, to this day I stand, witnessing both to small and great, saying no other things than those which the prophets and Moses said would come;
verse	44	26	23	that Christ would suffer, that He would be the first to rise from the dead, and would show light to the people and to the Gentiles."
verse	44	26	24	Now as he spoke for himself like this, Festus said with a loud voice, "Paul, you are beside yourself! Much learning is driving you mad!"
verse	44	26	25	But he said, "I am not mad, most noble Festus, but speak the words of truth and reason.
verse	44	26	26	Because the king, before whom I also speak freely, knows these things; because, I am convinced that none of these things are hidden from him, since this thing was not done in a corner.
verse	44	26	27	King Agrippa, do you believe the prophets? I know that you do believe."
verse	44	26	28	Then Agrippa said to Paul, "You almost persuade me to become a Christian."
verse	44	26	29	And Paul said, "I would to God that not only you, but also all who hear me today, might become both almost and altogether such as I am, except for these chains."
verse	44	26	30	When he had said these things, the king stood up, as well as the governor and Bernice and those who sat with them;
verse	44	26	31	and when they had gone aside, they talked among themselves, saying, "This man is doing nothing deserving of death or chains."
verse	44	26	32	Then Agrippa said to Festus, "This man might have been set free if he had not appealed to Caesar."
verse	44	27	1	And when it was determined that we should sail to Italy, they delivered Paul and some other prisoners to one named Julius, a centurion of the Augustan Regiment.
verse	44	27	2	So, entering into a ship of Adramyttium, we launched, meaning to sail along the coasts of Asia. One Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, was with us.
verse	44	27	3	And the next day we landed at Sidon. And Julius treated Paul kindly and gave him liberty to go to his friends and refresh himself.
verse	44	27	4	When we had launched from there, we sailed under Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.
verse	44	27	5	And when we had sailed over the sea which is off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.
verse	44	27	6	And there the centurion found an Alexandrian ship sailing to Italy, and he put us on board.
verse	44	27	7	And when we had sailed slowly many days, and arrived with difficulty off Cnidus, the wind not permitting us to proceed, we sailed under Crete off Salmone.
verse	44	27	8	And passing it with difficulty, we came to a place called The Fair Havens; nearby was the city of Lasea.
verse	44	27	9	Now when much time had been spent, and sailing was now dangerous because the Fast was already over, Paul advised them,
verse	44	27	10	and said to them, "Men, I perceive that this voyage will end with disaster and much loss, not only of the cargo and ship, but also our lives."
verse	44	27	11	Nevertheless the centurion believed the helmsman and the owner of the ship than those things which were spoken by Paul.
verse	44	27	12	And because the harbor was not suitable to winter in, the majority advised to set sail from there also, if by any means they might reach Phoenix, which is a harbor of Crete opening toward the southwest and northwest, and winter there.
verse	44	27	13	And when the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained their desire, leaving there, they sailed close by Crete.
verse	44	27	14	But not long after, a tempestuous wind arose against it, called Euroclydon.
verse	44	27	15	So when the ship was caught, and could not head into the wind, we let her drive.
verse	44	27	16	And running underneath an island which is called Clauda, we secured the smaller boat with difficulty.
verse	44	27	17	Which, when they had taken it on board, they used cables to undergird the ship; and fearing lest they should run aground on the sandbanks, they struck sail and so were driven.
verse	44	27	18	And because we were exceedingly tossed with a tempest, the next day they lightened the ship.
verse	44	27	19	And on the third day we threw the ship's tackle overboard with our own hands.
verse	44	27	20	Now when neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no small tempest beat on us, all hope that we would be saved was finally gone.
verse	44	27	21	But after long abstinence from food, then Paul stood in the midst of them and said, "Men, you should have listened to me, and not have untied from Crete and incurred this disaster and loss.
verse	44	27	22	And now I urge you to be optimistic, because there will be no loss of any man's life among you, but only of the ship.
verse	44	27	23	Because, there stood by me this night the angel of the God to whom I belong and whom I serve,
verse	44	27	24	saying, 'Do not be afraid, Paul; you must be brought before Caesar; and indeed God has granted you all those who sail with you.'
verse	44	27	25	Therefore men, take heart, because I believe God that it will be just as it was told me.
verse	44	27	26	However, we must run aground on a certain island."
verse	44	27	27	Now when the fourteenth night had come, as we were driven up and down in the Adriatic Sea, about midnight the sailors sensed that they were drawing near some land.
verse	44	27	28	And they took soundings and found it to be twenty fathoms; and when they had gone a little farther, they took soundings again and found it to be fifteen fathoms.
verse	44	27	29	Then, fearing lest we should run aground on the rocks, they dropped four anchors from the stern, and wished for day to come.
verse	44	27	30	And as the sailors were seeking to escape from the ship, when they had let down the small boat into the sea, pretending to be about to cast out anchors from the front of the ship,
verse	44	27	31	Paul said to the centurion and the soldiers, "Unless these men stay in the ship, you cannot all be saved."
verse	44	27	32	Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the small boat and let it fall off.
verse	44	27	33	And as day was about to dawn, Paul implored them all to take food, saying, "Today is the fourteenth day you have waited and continued fasting, and eaten nothing.
verse	44	27	34	Therefore I urge you to take some food, because this is for your survival, because not a hair will fall from the head of any of you."
verse	44	27	35	And when he had said these things, he took bread and gave thanks to God in the presence of them all; and when he had broken it he began to eat.
verse	44	27	36	Then they were all encouraged, and they also took some food.
verse	44	27	37	And in all we were two hundred and seventy six persons on the ship.
verse	44	27	38	So when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship and threw out the wheat into the sea.
verse	44	27	39	And when it was day, they did not recognize the land; but they observed a bay with a beach, onto which they planned to drive the ship if possible.
verse	44	27	40	And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves to the sea, untied the rudder ropes, hoisted the mainsail to the wind, and made for shore.
verse	44	27	41	And striking a place where two seas met, they ran the ship aground; and the front stuck fast and remained immovable, but the back part was being broken up by the violence of the waves.
verse	44	27	42	And the soldiers' instructions were to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim away and escape.
verse	44	27	43	But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, kept them from their purpose, and commanded that those who could swim should throw themselves first into the sea and get to land,
verse	44	27	44	and the rest, some on boards and some on broken pieces of the ship. And so it was that they all escaped safely to land.
verse	44	28	1	Now when they had escaped, they then discovered that the island was called Malta.
verse	44	28	2	And the natives showed us no small amount of kindness; because, they kindled a fire and made us all welcome, because of the falling rain and because of the cold.
verse	44	28	3	But when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and laid them on the fire, a viper came out because of the heat, and fastened on his hand.
verse	44	28	4	So when the natives saw the venomous creature hanging on his hand, they said to one another, "No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he has escaped the sea, yet justice does not allow to live."
verse	44	28	5	But he shook off the creature into the fire and felt no harm.
verse	44	28	6	However, they were expecting that he would swell up or suddenly fall down dead. But after they had looked for a long time and saw no harm come to him, they changed their minds and said that he was a god.
verse	44	28	7	In that region there was an estate of the leading citizen of the island, whose name was Publius, who received us and hosted us hospitably for three days.
verse	44	28	8	And it happened that the father of Publius lay sick of a fever and dysentery. Paul went in to him and prayed, and he laid his hands on him and healed him.
verse	44	28	9	So when this was done, the rest of those on the island who had diseases also came and were healed.
verse	44	28	10	They also honored us in many ways; and when we departed, they provided us with such things as were necessary.
verse	44	28	11	After three months we sailed in an Alexandrian ship whose figurehead was Castor and Pollux, which had wintered at the island.
verse	44	28	12	And landing at Syracuse, we stayed there for three days.
verse	44	28	13	From there we circled round and reached Rhegium. And after one day the south wind blew; and the next day we came to Puteoli,
verse	44	28	14	where we found brethren, and were invited to stay with them seven days. And so we went toward Rome.
verse	44	28	15	And from there, when the brethren heard about us, they came to meet us as far as Appii Forum and Three Inns. When Paul saw them, he thanked God and took courage.
verse	44	28	16	Now when we came to Rome, the centurion delivered the prisoners to the captain of the guard; but Paul was permitted to dwell by himself with the soldier who guarded him.
verse	44	28	17	And it came to pass after three days that Paul called the leaders of the Jews together. So when they had come together, he said to them: "Men and brethren, though I have done nothing against our people or the customs of our fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans,
verse	44	28	18	who, when they had examined me, wanted to let me go, because there were no grounds for putting me to death.
verse	44	28	19	But when the Jews spoke against it, I was compelled to appeal to Caesar, not that I had anything of which to accuse my nation.
verse	44	28	20	For this reason therefore I have called for you, to see you and speak with you, because for the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain."
verse	44	28	21	Then they said to him, "We neither received letters from Judea concerning you, nor have any of the brethren who came reported or spoken any evil of you.
verse	44	28	22	But we desire to hear from you what you think; for concerning this sect, we know that it is spoken against everywhere."
verse	44	28	23	So when they had appointed him a day, many came to him at his lodging, to whom he explained and testified of the kingdom of God, persuading them concerning Jesus from both the Law of Moses and out of the Prophets, from morning until evening.
verse	44	28	24	And some were persuaded by the things which were spoken, and some disbelieved.
verse	44	28	25	So when they did not agree among themselves, they departed after Paul had said one word: "The Holy Spirit spoke rightly through Isaiah the prophet to our fathers,
verse	44	28	26	saying, 'Go to this people and say: "Hearing you will hear, and shall not understand; and seeing you will see, and not perceive;
verse	44	28	27	Because the hearts of this people have grown dull. Their ears are hard of hearing, and their eyes they have closed, lest they should see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and should understand with their hearts, and be converted, then I could heal them."'
verse	44	28	28	"Therefore let it be known to you that the salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they will hear it!"
verse	44	28	29	And when he had said these words, the Jews departed and had a great dispute among themselves.
verse	44	28	30	Then Paul dwelt an entire two years in his own rented house, and received all who came to him,
verse	44	28	31	preaching the kingdom of God and teaching the things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ with all confidence, no one forbidding him.
verse	45	1	1	Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an apostle, separated to the gospel of God,
verse	45	1	2	which He had promised beforehand through His prophets in the Holy Scriptures,
verse	45	1	3	concerning His Son Jesus Christ our Lord, who was made of the seed of David according to the flesh,
verse	45	1	4	and declared to be the Son of God with power according to the Spirit of holiness, by the resurrection from the dead.
verse	45	1	5	By whom we have received grace and apostleship for obedience to the faith among all nations for His name,
verse	45	1	6	among whom you also are the called of Jesus Christ;
verse	45	1	7	To all who are in Rome, beloved of God, called to be saints: Grace to you and peace from God our Father, and the Lord Jesus Christ.
verse	45	1	8	First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is spoken of throughout the entire world.
verse	45	1	9	Because, God is my witness, whom I serve with my spirit in the gospel of His Son, that without ceasing I make mention of you always in my prayers,
verse	45	1	10	making request if, by some means, now at last I may have a prosperous journey by the will of God to come to you.
verse	45	1	11	Because, I long to see you, that I may impart to you some spiritual gift, so that you may be established;
verse	45	1	12	that is, that I may be encouraged together with you by the mutual faith both of you and me.
verse	45	1	13	Now I do not want you to be unaware, brethren, that I often planned to come to you, (but was hindered until now), that I might have some fruit among you also, just as among other Gentiles.
verse	45	1	14	I am a debtor both to the Greeks, and to the Barbarians, both to the wise, and to the unwise.
verse	45	1	15	So, as much as is in me, I am ready to preach the gospel to you who are in Rome also.
verse	45	1	16	Because, I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ, because it is the power of God to salvation to everyone who believes, for the Jew first, and also for the Greek.
verse	45	1	17	Because in it, the righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith; as it is written, "The just will live by faith."
verse	45	1	18	Because, the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who suppress the truth in unrighteousness,
verse	45	1	19	because what may be known of God is manifest in them, because God has shown it to them.
verse	45	1	20	Because, since the creation of the world His invisible attributes are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made, even His eternal power and Godhead; so that they are without excuse,
verse	45	1	21	because although they knew God, they did not glorify Him as God, nor were thankful, but became vain in their imaginations, and their foolish hearts were darkened.
verse	45	1	22	Professing themselves to be wise, they became fools,
verse	45	1	23	and changed the glory of the uncorruptible God into an image made like to corruptible man, and to birds and four footed animals and creeping things.
verse	45	1	24	Therefore God also gave them up to uncleanness through the lusts of their own hearts, to dishonor their own bodies among themselves,
verse	45	1	25	who changed the truth of God into lie, and worshiped and served the creature more than the Creator, who is blessed forever. Amen.
verse	45	1	26	For this reason God gave them over to vile passions. Because, even their women exchanged the natural use for what is against nature.
verse	45	1	27	And likewise also the men, leaving the natural use of the woman, burned in their lust for one another, men with men doing what is shameful, and receiving in themselves that penalty of their error which was due.
verse	45	1	28	And even as they did not like to retain God in their knowledge, God gave them over to a reprobate mind, to do those things which are not appropriate;
verse	45	1	29	being filled with all unrighteousness, sexual immorality, wickedness, covetousness, maliciousness; full of envy, murder, debate, deception, malignity; being whisperers,
verse	45	1	30	backbiters, haters of God, violent, proud, boasters, inventors of evil things, disobedient to parents,
verse	45	1	31	without understanding, covenant breakers, without natural affection, implacable, unmerciful;
verse	45	1	32	who knowing the judgment of God, that those who commit such things are worthy of death, not only do the same but approve those who do them.
verse	45	2	1	Therefore you are inexcusable, O man, whoever you are who judge, because, in whatever you judge another you condemn yourself; because you who judge practice the same things.
verse	45	2	2	But we are certain that the judgment of God is according to truth against those who commit such things.
verse	45	2	3	And do you think this, O man, you who judge those who do such things, and doing the same, that you will escape the judgment of God?
verse	45	2	4	Or do you despise the riches of His goodness, forbearance, and longsuffering, not knowing that the goodness of God leads you to repentance?
verse	45	2	5	But according to your hardness and your impenitent heart you are treasuring up for yourself wrath in the day of wrath and revelation of the righteous judgment of God,
verse	45	2	6	who "will render to each one according to his deeds":
verse	45	2	7	eternal life to those who by patient continuance in doing good seek for glory, honor, and immortality;
verse	45	2	8	but to those who are contentious and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness, indignation and wrath,
verse	45	2	9	tribulation and anguish, on every soul of man who does evil, of the Jew first and also of the Gentile;
verse	45	2	10	but glory, honor, and peace to everyone who works what is good, to the Jew first and also to the Gentile.
verse	45	2	11	Because there is no personal favoritism with God.
verse	45	2	12	Because, as many as have sinned without law will also perish without law, and as many as have sinned in the law will be judged by the law
verse	45	2	13	(because, not the hearers of the law are just in the sight of God, but the doers of the law will be justified;
verse	45	2	14	because, when the Gentiles, who do not have the law, by nature do the things contained in the law, these, although not having the law, are a law to themselves,
verse	45	2	15	who show the work of the law written in their hearts, their conscience also bearing witness, and between themselves their thoughts accusing or else excusing them)
verse	45	2	16	in the day when God will judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my gospel.
verse	45	2	17	Indeed you are called a Jew, and rest in the law, and make your boast in God,
verse	45	2	18	and know His will, and approve the things that are more excellent, being instructed out of the law,
verse	45	2	19	and are confident that you yourself are a guide to the blind, a light to those who are in darkness,
verse	45	2	20	an instructor of the foolish, a teacher of babes, who has the form of knowledge and of the truth in the law.
verse	45	2	21	You, therefore, who teach another, do you not teach yourself? You who preach that a man should not steal, do you steal?
verse	45	2	22	You who say, "A man should not commit adultery," do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you commit sacrilege?
verse	45	2	23	You who make your boast in the law, do you dishonor God through breaking the law?
verse	45	2	24	Because, "the name of God is blasphemed among the Gentiles because of you," as it is written.
verse	45	2	25	Because, circumcision is indeed profitable if you keep the law; but if you are a breaker of the law, your circumcision has become uncircumcision.
verse	45	2	26	Therefore, if an uncircumcised man keeps the righteous requirements of the law, will not his uncircumcision be counted as circumcision?
verse	45	2	27	And will not the physically uncircumcised, if he fulfills the law, judge you who, even with your written code and circumcision, are a transgressor of the law?
verse	45	2	28	Because, he is not a Jew who is one outwardly, nor is that circumcision that which is outward in the flesh;
verse	45	2	29	but he is a Jew who is one inwardly; and circumcision is that of the heart, in the Spirit, and not in the letter; whose praise is not from men but from God.
verse	45	3	1	What advantage then has the Jew, or what is the profit of circumcision?
verse	45	3	2	Much in every way! Chiefly because to them were committed the oracles of God.
verse	45	3	3	Because, what if some did not believe? Will their unbelief make the faith of God without effect?
verse	45	3	4	God forbid! Indeed, let God be true but every man a liar. As it is written: "That You may be justified in Your words, and may overcome when You are judged."
verse	45	3	5	But if our unrighteousness demonstrates the righteousness of God, what shall we say? Is God unjust who inflicts wrath? (I speak as a man.)
verse	45	3	6	God forbid! Because then how will God judge the world?
verse	45	3	7	Because, if the truth of God has increased through my lie to His glory, why am I also still judged as a sinner?
verse	45	3	8	So why not just say, "Let us do evil that good may come," As we are slanderously reported and as some affirm that we say? Their damnation is just.
verse	45	3	9	What then? Are we better than they? Not at all. Because we have previously charged both Jews and Greeks that they are all under sin.
verse	45	3	10	As it is written: "There is none righteous, no, not one;
verse	45	3	11	There is none who understands; there is none who seeks after God.
verse	45	3	12	They have all turned aside; they have together become unprofitable; there is none who does good, no, not one."
verse	45	3	13	"Their throat is an open tomb; with their tongues they have practiced deceit"; "The poison of asps is under their lips";
verse	45	3	14	"Whose mouth is full of cursing and bitterness."
verse	45	3	15	"Their feet are swift to shed blood;
verse	45	3	16	destruction and misery are in their ways;
verse	45	3	17	and the way of peace they have not known."
verse	45	3	18	"There is no reverence of God before their eyes."
verse	45	3	19	Now we know that whatever the law says, it says to those who are under the law, that every mouth may be stopped, and all the world may become guilty before God.
verse	45	3	20	Therefore by the deeds of the law no flesh will be justified in His sight, because by the law is the knowledge of sin.
verse	45	3	21	But now the righteousness of God apart from the law is revealed, being witnessed by the Law and the Prophets,
verse	45	3	22	even the righteousness of God, which is by the faith of Jesus Christ, to all and on all those who believe. Because there is no difference;
verse	45	3	23	because all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,
verse	45	3	24	being justified freely by His grace through the redemption that is in Christ Jesus,
verse	45	3	25	whom God foreordained to be a propitiation through faith in His blood, to demonstrate His righteousness, for the remission of sins that were previously committed, through the forbearance of God;
verse	45	3	26	to demonstrate at the present time His righteousness, that He might be just and the justifier of the one who believes in Jesus.
verse	45	3	27	Where is boasting then? It is excluded. By what law? Of works? No, but by the law of faith.
verse	45	3	28	Therefore we conclude that a man is justified by faith without the deeds of the law.
verse	45	3	29	Is He the God of the Jews only? Is He not also the God of the Gentiles? Yes, of the Gentiles also,
verse	45	3	30	since there is one God who will justify the circumcised by faith and the uncircumcised through faith.
verse	45	3	31	Do we then make void the law through faith? God forbid! On the contrary, we establish the law.
verse	45	4	1	What then shall we say that Abraham our father has found according to the flesh?
verse	45	4	2	Because, if Abraham was justified by works, he has something to boast about, but not before God.
verse	45	4	3	Because what does the Scripture say? "Abraham believed God, and it was accounted to him for righteousness."
verse	45	4	4	Now to him who works, the wages are not counted as grace but as debt.
verse	45	4	5	But to him who does not work but believes on Him who justifies the ungodly, his faith is accounted for righteousness,
verse	45	4	6	just as David also describes the blessedness of the man to whom God imputes righteousness apart from works:
verse	45	4	7	Saying "Blessed are those whose iniquities are forgiven, and whose sins are covered;
verse	45	4	8	blessed is the man to whom the LORD will not impute sin."
verse	45	4	9	Does this blessedness then come upon the circumcised only, or upon the uncircumcised also? Because we say that faith was accounted to Abraham for righteousness.
verse	45	4	10	How then was it accounted? While he was circumcised, or uncircumcised? Not while circumcised, but while uncircumcised.
verse	45	4	11	And he received the sign of circumcision, a seal of the righteousness of the faith which he had while still uncircumcised, that he might be the father of all those who believe, though they are uncircumcised, that righteousness might be imputed to them also,
verse	45	4	12	and the father of circumcision to those who not only are of the circumcision, but who also walk in the steps of the faith of our father Abraham, which he had while still uncircumcised.
verse	45	4	13	Because, the promise that he would be the heir of the world was not to Abraham or to his seed through the law, but through the righteousness of faith.
verse	45	4	14	Because, if those who are of the law are heirs, faith is made void and the promise made of no effect,
verse	45	4	15	because, the law brings about wrath; because where there is no law there is no transgression.
verse	45	4	16	Therefore it is of faith that it might be by grace, so that the promise might be certain to all the seed, not only to those who are of the law, but also to those who are of the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all
verse	45	4	17	(as it is written, "I have made you a father of many nations") in the presence of Him whom he believed, even God, who gives life to the dead and calls those things which do not exist as though they did;
verse	45	4	18	who, contrary to hope, in hope believed, so that he would become the father of many nations, according to what was spoken, "So will your seed be."
verse	45	4	19	And not being weak in faith, he did not consider his own body, already dead (since he was about a hundred years old), nor the deadness of Sarah's womb.
verse	45	4	20	He did not waver at the promise of God through unbelief, but was strong in faith, giving glory to God,
verse	45	4	21	and being fully persuaded that what He had promised He was also able to perform.
verse	45	4	22	And therefore "it was imputed to him for righteousness."
verse	45	4	23	Now it was not written for his sake alone that it was imputed to him,
verse	45	4	24	but also for us. It will be imputed to us, if we believe in Him who raised up Jesus our Lord from the dead,
verse	45	4	25	who was delivered for our offenses, and was raised again because of our justification.
verse	45	5	1	Therefore, having been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ,
verse	45	5	2	by whom also we have access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and rejoice in hope of the glory of God.
verse	45	5	3	And not only that, but we also glory in tribulations, knowing that tribulation produces perseverance;
verse	45	5	4	and perseverance, character; and character, hope.
verse	45	5	5	Now hope does not make us ashamed, because the love of God has been poured out in our hearts by the Holy Spirit who was given to us.
verse	45	5	6	Because, when we were still without strength, in due time Christ died for the ungodly.
verse	45	5	7	Because, scarcely for a righteous man will one die; yet perhaps for a good man someone would even dare to die.
verse	45	5	8	But God demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.
verse	45	5	9	Much more then, having now been justified by His blood, we will be saved from wrath through Him.
verse	45	5	10	Because, if when we were enemies we were reconciled to God through the death of His Son, much more, having been reconciled, we will be saved by His life.
verse	45	5	11	And not only that, but we also rejoice in God through our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom we have now received the atonement.
verse	45	5	12	Therefore, just as by one man sin entered the world, and death by sin, and thus death spread to everyone, because all sinned:
verse	45	5	13	(Because, until the law sin was in the world, but sin is not imputed when there is no law.
verse	45	5	14	Nevertheless death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over those who had not sinned according to the likeness of the transgression of Adam, who is a type of Him who was to come.
verse	45	5	15	But the free gift is not like the offense. Because, if through the one man's offense many died, much more the grace of God and the gift by grace, which is by one Man, Jesus Christ, has abounded to many.
verse	45	5	16	And the gift is not like that which came through the one who sinned. Because the judgment which came from one offense resulted in condemnation, but the free gift which came from many offenses resulted in justification.
verse	45	5	17	Because, if by the one man's offense death reigned by one, much more those who receive abundance of grace and of the gift of righteousness will reign in life by One, Jesus Christ.)
verse	45	5	18	Therefore, as by one man's offense judgment came upon all mankind, resulting in condemnation, even so by one Man's righteous act the free gift came to all mankind, resulting in justification of life.
verse	45	5	19	Because, as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so also by the obedience of One many will be made righteous.
verse	45	5	20	Moreover the law entered that the offense might abound. But where sin abounded, grace abounded much more,
verse	45	5	21	so that as sin reigned in death, even so grace might reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verse	45	6	1	What shall we say then? Shall we continue in sin that grace may abound?
verse	45	6	2	God forbid! How shall we who died to sin live any longer in it?
verse	45	6	3	Or do you not know that as many of us as were baptized into Jesus Christ were baptized into His death?
verse	45	6	4	Therefore we were buried with Him by baptism into death, that just as Christ was raised up from the dead by the glory of the Father, even so we also should walk in newness of life.
verse	45	6	5	Because, if we have been planted together in the likeness of His death, we will be also in the likeness of His resurrection,
verse	45	6	6	knowing this, that our old man was crucified with Him, that the body of sin might be destroyed, that we should no longer serve sin.
verse	45	6	7	Because he who has died has been freed from sin.
verse	45	6	8	Now if we died with Christ, we believe that we will also live with Him,
verse	45	6	9	knowing that Christ, having been raised from the dead, dies no more. Death no longer has dominion over Him.
verse	45	6	10	Because, in the death that He died, He died to sin once; but the life that He lives, He lives to God.
verse	45	6	11	Likewise you also, reckon yourselves to be dead indeed to sin, but alive to God in Jesus Christ our Lord.
verse	45	6	12	Therefore do not let sin reign in your mortal body, that you should obey it in its lusts.
verse	45	6	13	And do not present your members as instruments of unrighteousness to sin, but present yourselves to God as those who are alive from the dead, and your members as instruments of righteousness to God.
verse	45	6	14	Because, sin will not have dominion over you, because you are not under law but under grace.
verse	45	6	15	What then? Shall we sin because we are not under law but under grace? God forbid!
verse	45	6	16	Do you not know that to whom you present yourselves servants to obey, you are that one's servant whom you obey, whether of sin leading to death, or of obedience leading to righteousness?
verse	45	6	17	But God be thanked that though you were servants of sin, yet you obeyed from the heart that form of doctrine which was delivered to you.
verse	45	6	18	And having been set free from sin, you became servants of righteousness.
verse	45	6	19	I speak in human terms because of the weakness of your flesh. Because, just as you presented your members as servants of uncleanness, and of iniquity leading to more iniquity, so now present your members as servants of righteousness for holiness.
verse	45	6	20	Because when you were servants of sin, you were free from righteousness.
verse	45	6	21	What fruit did you have then in the things of which you are now ashamed? Because the end of those things is death.
verse	45	6	22	But now having been set free from sin, and having become servants of God, you have your fruit to holiness, and the end, everlasting life.
verse	45	6	23	Because, the wages of sin is death, but the gift of God is eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.
verse	45	7	1	Or do you not know, brethren (because I speak to those who know the law), that the law has dominion over a man as long as he lives?
verse	45	7	2	Because, the woman who has a husband is bound by the law to her husband as long as he lives. But if the husband dies, she is released from the law of her husband.
verse	45	7	3	So then if, while her husband lives, she marries another man, she will be called an adulteress; but if her husband dies, she is free from that law, so that she is no adulteress, though she has married another man.
verse	45	7	4	Therefore, my brethren, you also have become dead to the law by the body of Christ, that you may be married to another, even to Him who was raised from the dead, that we should bear fruit to God.
verse	45	7	5	Because, when we were in the flesh, the sinful passions which were through the law were at work in our members to bear fruit to death.
verse	45	7	6	But now we have been delivered from the law, that which we were held by being dead, so that we should serve in the newness of the spirit and not in the oldness of the letter.
verse	45	7	7	What shall we say then? Is the law sin? God forbid! On the contrary, I would not have known sin except through the law. Because, I would not have known covetousness unless the law had said, "You shall not covet."
verse	45	7	8	But sin, taking opportunity by the commandment, produced in me all manner of evil desire. Because apart from the law sin was dead.
verse	45	7	9	Because, I was alive once without the law, but when the commandment came, sin revived and I died.
verse	45	7	10	And the commandment, which was appointed for life, I found to bring death.
verse	45	7	11	Because sin, taking occasion by the commandment, deceived me, and by it killed me.
verse	45	7	12	Therefore the law is holy, and the commandment holy and just and good.
verse	45	7	13	Has then what is good become death to me? God forbid! But sin, that it might appear sin, was producing death in me by what is good, so that sin through the commandment might become exceedingly sinful.
verse	45	7	14	Because, we know that the law is spiritual, but I am carnal, sold under sin.
verse	45	7	15	Because what I am doing, I do not approve. Because what I will to do, that I do not do; but what I hate, that I do.
verse	45	7	16	If, then, I do what I will not to do, I agree with the law that it is good.
verse	45	7	17	But now, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells in me.
verse	45	7	18	Because, I know that in me (that is, in my flesh) nothing good dwells; because, to will is present with me, but how to perform what is good I do not find.
verse	45	7	19	Because, the good that I will to do, I do not do; but the evil I will not to do, that I do.
verse	45	7	20	Now if I do what I will not to do, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells in me.
verse	45	7	21	I find then a law, that when I will to do good, evil is present with me.
verse	45	7	22	Because, I delight in the law of God according to the inward man.
verse	45	7	23	But I see another law in my members, warring against the law of my mind, and bringing me into captivity to the law of sin which is in my members.
verse	45	7	24	O wretched man that I am! Who shall deliver me from the body of this death?
verse	45	7	25	I thank God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, with the mind I myself serve the law of God, but with the flesh the law of sin.
verse	45	8	1	There is therefore now no condemnation to those who are in Christ Jesus, who do not walk according to the flesh, but according to the Spirit.
verse	45	8	2	Because, the law of the Spirit of life in Christ Jesus has made me free from the law of sin and death.
verse	45	8	3	Because what the law could not do in that it was weak through the flesh, God did by sending His own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh, and for sin: condemned sin in the flesh,
verse	45	8	4	that the righteous requirement of the law might be fulfilled in us who do not walk according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.
verse	45	8	5	Because, those who live according to the flesh mind the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit, the things of the Spirit.
verse	45	8	6	Because, to be carnally minded is death, but to be spiritually minded is life and peace.
verse	45	8	7	Because, the carnal mind is enmity against God; because it is not subject to the law of God, nor indeed can it be.
verse	45	8	8	So then, those who are in the flesh cannot please God.
verse	45	8	9	But you are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if indeed the Spirit of God dwells in you. Now if anyone does not have the Spirit of Christ, he is not His.
verse	45	8	10	And if Christ is in you, the body is dead because of sin, but the Spirit is life because of righteousness.
verse	45	8	11	But if the Spirit of Him who raised up Jesus from the dead dwells in you, He who raised up Christ from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies by His Spirit who dwells in you.
verse	45	8	12	Therefore, brethren, we are debtors, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh.
verse	45	8	13	Because, if you live according to the flesh you will die; but if through the Spirit you put to death the deeds of the body, you will live.
verse	45	8	14	Because, as many as are led by the Spirit of God, these are sons of God.
verse	45	8	15	Because, you did not receive the spirit of bondage again to fear, but you have received the Spirit of adoption by whom we cry out, "Abba, Father."
verse	45	8	16	The Spirit Himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of God,
verse	45	8	17	and if children, then heirs, heirs of God and joint heirs with Christ, providing we suffer with Him, that we may also be glorified together.
verse	45	8	18	Because, I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory which will be revealed in us.
verse	45	8	19	Because, the earnest expectation of the creature waits for the revealing of the sons of God.
verse	45	8	20	Because, the creature was subjected to vanity, not willingly, but because of Him who subjected it in hope;
verse	45	8	21	because, the creature itself also will be delivered from the bondage of corruption into the glorious liberty of the children of God.
verse	45	8	22	Because, we know that the entire creation groans and labors with birth pangs together until now.
verse	45	8	23	And not only they, but we also who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, even we ourselves groan within ourselves, eagerly waiting for the adoption, that is the redemption of our body.
verse	45	8	24	Because, we were saved by hope, but hope that is seen is not hope; because why does one still hope for what he sees?
verse	45	8	25	But if we hope for what we do not see, then we eagerly wait for it with perseverance.
verse	45	8	26	Likewise the Spirit also helps in our weaknesses. Because, we do not know what we should pray for as we ought, but the Spirit Himself makes intercession for us with groanings which cannot be uttered.
verse	45	8	27	Now He who searches the hearts knows what the mind of the Spirit is, because He makes intercession for the saints according to the will of God.
verse	45	8	28	And we know that all things work together for good to those who love God, to those who are the called according to His purpose.
verse	45	8	29	Because, whom He foreknew, He also predestined to be conformed to the image of His Son, that He might be the firstborn among many brethren.
verse	45	8	30	Moreover whom He predestined, these He also called; whom He called, these He also justified; and whom He justified, these He also glorified.
verse	45	8	31	What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?
verse	45	8	32	He who did not spare His own Son, but delivered Him up for us all, how will He not with Him also freely give us all things?
verse	45	8	33	Who shall bring a charge against God's elect? It is God who justifies.
verse	45	8	34	Who is he who condemns? It is Christ who died, and furthermore is also risen, who is even at the right hand of God, who also makes intercession for us.
verse	45	8	35	Who shall separate us from the love of Christ? Shall tribulation, or distress, or persecution, or famine, or nakedness, or peril, or sword?
verse	45	8	36	As it is written: "For Your sake we are killed all day long; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter."
verse	45	8	37	Yet in all these things we are more than conquerors through Him who loved us.
verse	45	8	38	Because, I am persuaded that neither death nor life, nor angels nor principalities nor powers, nor things present nor things to come,
